title: Optimize Hokey for longer texts
description: ANALYSIS COMPLETE: Hokey is 4-8x slower than comparable glitchlings on long texts (83ms vs 11-20ms for 250k chars). Created 6 optimization subtasks targeting: 1) redundant to_lowercase(), 2) Aho-Corasick for digraphs, 3) reducing HashMap cloning, 4) eliminating double tokenization, 5) caching char collections, 6) optimizing excluded() checks. Subtasks: glitchlings-1ed8.1 through glitchlings-1ed8.6

title: Hokey: Avoid redundant to_lowercase() calls
description: In hokey.rs, to_lowercase() is called multiple times for the same word: in compute_features(), phonotactic(), and find_stretch_site(). Cache the lowercase version once during tokenization or analysis pass.
notes: Implemented: lowercase cached in TokenInfo during tokenization, used in sentiment()

title: Hokey: Use Aho-Corasick for digraph detection
description: In phonotactic(), iterating through 15 digraph patterns with str::contains() is O(n*patterns). Use an Aho-Corasick automaton (like OCR_AUTOMATON in resources.rs) for O(n+m) multi-pattern matching. Same applies to sentiment lexicon lookups which iterate through window words.
notes: Deferred: Aho-Corasick would have minimal impact given the algorithmic bottleneck

title: Hokey: Reduce HashMap cloning in select_candidates
description: In select_candidates(), candidates are cloned multiple times: once when grouping by clause, again when building provisional lists, and when extending selected. Consider using indices/references instead of cloning StretchCandidate structs which contain cloned StretchFeatures.
notes: Implemented: indices-based candidate selection instead of struct cloning

title: Hokey: Use TextBuffer tokenization instead of double tokenization
description: Hokey has its own tokenise() method using regex while TextBuffer also tokenizes during from_owned(). The GlitchOp::apply receives a TextBuffer which has already been tokenized. Refactor to use the buffer's existing segments instead of re-tokenizing, which would avoid the regex overhead and string allocations for longer texts.
notes: Investigation complete. Hokey's algorithmic complexity is the bottleneck - 40K tokens with multi-feature analysis vs Ekkokin's O(1) lookup. Applied optimizations (cached lowercase, clause_start flag, lazy caching) but minimal improvement. Would need fundamental algorithm changes for significant speedup.

title: Hokey: Cache chars() collections in find_stretch_site
description: find_stretch_site() calls word.chars().collect() and then lower.chars().collect() separately. For long words being processed many times, pre-compute and reuse these character vectors. Also the vowel_clusters function could be inlined or its results cached.
notes: Implemented: TokenCache with cached chars and alpha_indices

title: Hokey: Optimize excluded() checks with early returns
description: The excluded() function iterates through tokens[..index] looking backwards for clause boundaries. For very long texts with many tokens, this linear scan is expensive. Consider: (1) caching clause_start flags in TokenInfo during tokenization, (2) checking cheaper conditions first (like alpha_count) before the expensive Title case backward scan.
notes: Implemented: at_clause_start flag computed during tokenization

title: Epic: Functional Purity Refactor
description:
Refactor the codebase to explicitly separate functionally pure and impure code. The goal is to produce a codebase that discourages agents from writing unnecessary defensive code by keeping defensive code and functional code separate. This separation makes it clear where validation happens (boundary layers) vs. where trusted transformations occur (core logic).

## Motivation
AI coding agents tend to add defensive checks throughout code even when inputs are already validated at boundaries. By architecturally separating pure transformation logic from impure IO/validation layers, we make it obvious that core functions can trust their inputs.

## Child Tasks
Tasks are linked via dependency chains. Start with glitchlings-0176 (Identify pure transformation functions) and follow the dependency tree to completion.

## Success Criteria
1. Pure transformation modules have no defensive None checks
2. All validation happens at clearly marked boundary layers
3. RNG state managed at boundaries, pure functions accept values
4. Documentation guides contributors on maintaining separation
5. AGENTS.md instructs AI agents on proper patterns

title: Investigate Typogre+Mim1c Gaggle determinism issue
description:
Fixed nondeterminism in gaggle+seed combinations by using BTreeMap instead of HashMap in Rust code to ensure deterministic iteration order. Changes:

1. mim1c.rs: Changed HOMOGLYPH_TABLE from HashMap to BTreeMap for deterministic key ordering during JSON parsing and iteration. Also changed the by_segment HashMap to sort keys before iteration.

2. glitch_ops.rs: Fixed 3 HashMap iterations (OcrArtifactsOp, ZeroWidthOp, QuotePairsOp) to sort segment indices before processing.

Root cause: Rust's HashMap uses RandomState with per-process random seeds, causing non-deterministic iteration order across process invocations. This affected:
- HOMOGLYPH_TABLE initialization where multiple JSON keys map to the same first character
- Segment grouping operations where HashMap iteration determined processing order

The fix ensures identical results across process invocations when using the same seed.
